title: [Bug]: openclaw completion outputs non-code log messages to stdout, causing syntax errors when sourced
body:
Description
When using source <(openclaw completion --shell bash) in .bashrc, the shell reports a command not found error. This is because the command outputs diagnostic/log messages (e.g., [plugins] feishu_doc...) to stdout along with the completion script.

Since these logs are not valid Bash commands, the shell attempts to execute them, leading to: -bash: $`\E[35m[plugins]\E[39m`: command not found

Environment
OS: Linux

Shell: Bash

OpenClaw Version: 2026.1.30

Plugins installed: @m1heng-clawd/feishu

Steps to Reproduce
Install feishu plugin to chat.

Run openclaw completion --shell bash in a terminal.

Observe that the output contains both the Bash completion script and plain-text log messages like [plugins] ....

Try to source the output: source <(openclaw completion --shell bash).

Suggested Solutions for Developers
1. Redirect Logs to stderr (Recommended)
All diagnostic messages, status updates, and plugin registration logs should be directed to stderr instead of stdout. In your code (Golang/Node.js/etc.), ensure that [plugins] logs are printed via console.error() or fprintf(stderr, ...). This ensures that source <(...) only captures the functional script.

2. Add a --quiet Flag
Implement a -q or --quiet flag for the completion command to suppress all non-essential output.

3. Check for TTY
Detect if the output is a TTY. If the output is being piped or redirected (like in source <(...)), disable ANSI color codes and decorative logs automatically.

Temporary Workaround for Users
Until this is fixed, users must manually filter the output:

```Bash
# Filter by identifying valid bash completion keywords
source <(openclaw completion --shell bash 2>/dev/null | grep -a "^complete")
```
